description:
[Salted eggs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salted_duck_egg) are usually made from duck eggs, preserved by soaking in brine and then packing in charcoal, often eaten with congee. The yolk is used as the molten custard in “lava” (流沙) buns.

**Characters**

{鹹} is *salty*, and {蛋} is *egg*, so {鹹蛋} is *salty egg*.

{鴨} is *duck* (aap in Cantonese, yā in Mandarin), so sometimes the word used is {鹹鴨蛋}, *salty duck egg* (*hàahm aap dáan* in Cantonese, *xián yā dàn* in Mandarin)

[Soy eggs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soy_egg) are boiled and then soaked in a soy sauce mixture, sometimes served with congee or with rice.

**Personal Taste**

I like the [Momofuku recipe](https://food52.com/recipes/35930-momofuku-s-soy-sauce-eggs).

{滷} refers to stewing in a mixture of soy sauce and spices, often translated as *braised* or *marinated*, and {蛋} is *egg*, so {滷蛋} is basically *soy-marinated egg*.

[Tea eggs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tea_egg) are boiled then cracked then boiled again or soaked in a mixture of soy sauce and spices. Also known as “marble egg” as the cracked shells create a marbled appearance.

**Characters**

{茶葉} is *tea leaves*({茶} is [tea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tea), {葉} is *leaf*), and {蛋} is “*egg*, so {茶葉蛋} is *tea leaves egg*.

[Egg foo young](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egg_foo_young) (or egg foo yung, or egg fu yung...anyway, it's the Cantonese pronunciation) is a crispy pan-fried, or sometimes even deep-fried, omelet containing vegetables such as mushrooms, bean sprouts, and water chestnuts, and sometimes including meat such as chicken, cha siu, or shrimp. The Chinese-American version is usually smothered in gravy, because, America, giving it the chicken-fried steak treatment.

**Personal note**

I only had this dish recently (just for this app) and didn't realize it's a real Chinese dish. I thought someone just made up the name.

**Characters**

{芙蓉}is *lotus* and {蛋} is *egg*, so {芙蓉蛋} is *lotus egg* (and really, the English should be *foo young egg*).
